content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table, with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in hours,” and the heading for row 2 is “A of t, in gallons.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. A of t is 10. Column 2. t is 5. A of t is 18. Column 3. t is 15. A of t is 25. Column 4. t is 30. A of t is 16. Column 5. t is 35. A of t is 8."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="7em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(hours)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>15</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>30</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>35</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(gallons)</mtext></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>18</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>25</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>16</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> The number of gallons of olive oil in a tank at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours and <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 35"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="A of t "><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at selected times <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. (a) Use the data in the table to estimate the rate at which the number of gallons of olive oil in the tank is changing at time <math alttext="t equals 10 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours. Show the computations that lead to your answer. Indicate units of measure.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table, with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in hours,” and the heading for row 2 is “A of t, in gallons.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. A of t is 10. Column 2. t is 5. A of t is 18. Column 3. t is 15. A of t is 25. Column 4. t is 30. A of t is 16. Column 5. t is 35. A of t is 8."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="7em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(hours)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>15</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>30</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>35</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(gallons)</mtext></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>18</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>25</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>16</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> The number of gallons of olive oil in a tank at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours and <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 35"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="A of t "><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at selected times <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. (a) Use the data in the table to estimate the rate at which the number of gallons of olive oil in the tank is changing at time <math alttext="t equals 10 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours. Show the computations that lead to your answer. Indicate units of measure.

(b) For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, is there a time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at which <math alttext="A prime of t, equals one fifth "><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(c) The number of gallons of olive oil in the tank at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is also modeled by the function <math alttext="G"><mstyle><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined by <math alttext="G of t equals, 5 t, minus two thirds times, open parenthesis, t plus 9, close parenthesis, raised to the three halves power, plus 28"><mstyle><mrow><mi>G</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>28</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours and <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 35"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on the model, at what time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 35"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, is the number of gallons of olive oil in the tank an absolute maximum? Justify your answer.

(d) For the function <math alttext="G"><mstyle><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined in part (c), the locally linear approximation near <math alttext="t equals 7 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is used to approximate <math alttext="G of 8"><mstyle><mrow><mi>G</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is this approximation an overestimate or an underestimate for the value of <math alttext="G of 8"><mstyle><mrow><mi>G</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

topic.text: 2.3: Estimating Derivatives of a Function at a Point

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
